076790592X|5.0|Tuesdays with Morrie offers answers to any person in search of the secrets of life. The book stresses how one can be educated about life by others, especially elders, in addition to our own experiences. Furthermore, if one is positive then one will be able to see the learning opportunities behind ones difficult moments. Consequently, bad events change from only being about suffering to being about valuable life lessons. Mitch Alboms novel is an example of how to face life with courage and how to learn about life from ones hard times.<BR>The novel is a true account of a student and his professors conversations about life. Not long after Mitchs college graduation, he was inspired to throw himself deeply into his career. Gradually, Mitch lost contact with his mentor and professor, Morrie Schwartz, with whom he had a tight relationship. Through a coincidence, Mitch became reunited with his college professor and from that point, they agreed to meet on Tuesdays to discuss life. The novel describes their time together as they talk about life and its secrets.<BR> Tuesdays with Morrie, might be considered a self-help book, but it is not. The novel is quite different from other books that cover lifes issues since its format is simple, direct and it does not make one feel as if they are being preached to. In addition, the books topics are easy to relate to since they are practical and universal. Morries character is very inspiring since he has an optimistic and courageous attitude towards life, in spite of his obstacles. I learned a lot from Morries experiences, which have made me think about the meaning of life more. <BR> The main theme of the book is to love, forgive and live positively. Unlike most people, Morrie chose to look beyond his obstacles, have a positive attitude and express his love for his family and friends. Consequently, he was able to live happily and created an example for every reader to follow. The book is an emotional journey that I strongly recommend everyone to take.
B00018D44U|5.0|Having listened to Norah Jones' Feels Like Home, I now see that the Pete Malick CD was more than just a stopgap release for this long-awaited jewel, but more of what she could do.  While some of the songs have the same relaxing inflection and instruments as Come Away From Me, Norah introduces styles ranging from blues, folk, and even bluegrass.  And the presence of other instruments, such as strings, electric guitar, and Hammond organ shows her styling evolving.  Cute publishing name for her songs--Muthajones Music.<br />The pronounced rhythm section of slit drums and acoustic guitar on &quot;Sunrise&quot; make it a track that wouldn't make it on Come Away With Me.<br />The bluesy/country-ish  &quot;What Am I To You?&quot; with its electric guitar and Wurlizter electric piano is a throwback to her music with Pete Malick.  Here she asks in the chorus:  &quot;I'll love you when you're blue/but tell me darlin' true/what am I to you?&quot;<br />&quot;Those Sweet Words&quot; starts out with that melodic piano, backing drums and soft vocals in the same light jazz manner as &quot;Feelin' The Same Way&quot; from her debut.  Ditto for &quot;Carnival Town,&quot; which also sports a cello and viola.  The use of the carnival as an analogy for life is interesting, how one looks down as the ferris wheel reaches its apex, or the brief laugh a clown gives one, i.e. it's lonely at the top, and life goes on after the thrill of a brief moment is gone.  When Norah asks &quot;Is it lonely?/lonely/lonely&quot; in the chorus, I can sense a silent &quot;yes&quot; being answered within.<br />&quot;In The Morning&quot; is kind of uptempo jazz/folk number about the aftermath of an affair, with these clever lines:  &quot;Funny how my favourite shirt/smells more like you than me.&quot;  That Wurlitzer piano playing indeed reminds me of mellow 70's music.<br />The analogy of a swift current to life and the fish as everyone else who seems with it is shown in the introspective &quot;Toes.&quot;  The first verse I can relate to:  &quot;The current is strong from what I've heard/it'll whisk you down the stream/but I never seem to have the tune/so my toes just touch the water.&quot;  Lyrically, one of my favourites here.<br />The humility felt by a single mother who's broken down on the road and is forced to call her ex, who's now making something of his life and has another woman, is in the sobering &quot;Humble Me&quot;, which features only a pump organ, a prominent resonator guitar, and bass.  The protagonist's feeling guilty in this song.<br />The feeling of hesitancy in rejoining the world, meeting a special someone is felt in the slow and bluesy &quot;Above Ground&quot; of a woman living underground, with nothing but her thoughts and a ceiling fan above her.  The promise is that &quot;I'll be with you someday&quot;, but when?<br />She does two covers here, Townes Van Zandt's &quot;Be Here To Love Me&quot; and Tom Waits' &quot;The Long Way Home.&quot;  There's a folky/country feel to it, but the bulk of it Norah accompanied by the bass and the tapping on a box, making it a nice minimalist number.<br />Norah tackles an upbeat folky/bluegrass number, &quot;Creepin' In&quot; which features Dolly Parton as guest vocalist.  There's an interesting double meaning here.  Verse one goes &quot;There's a big hole/that's gone right through the sole.&quot;  Hence the water goes creepin' in.  Well, in the final chorus, instead of going &quot;and once it has begun/won't stop until it's done&quot; it goes &quot;and once you have begun/don't stop until you're done.&quot;  It's almost as if she sang in the repeat of the first verse &quot;that's gone right through my soul&quot; instead of &quot;my sole.&quot;  Clever, that.<br />The last two numbers could belong on Come Away With Me, the daydreamy country/jazz &quot;The Prettiest Thing&quot; and melodic 40's piano jazz of &quot;Don't Miss You At All&quot;, which includes portions of Duke Ellington's &quot;Melancholia.&quot;This is quite a melancholy and reflective piece, of watching falling snow and thinking the title.  One of my favourites here.<br />Topping a masterpiece like Come Away With Me would be next to impossible, but lo and behold, Muthajones has incorporated other styles in her light and mellow jazz inflections.  The wait has been worth it, the music still melodic and wonderful.  Muthajones does it again!This is quite a melancholy and reflective piece, of watching falling snow and thinking the title.  One of my favourites here.<br />Topping a masterpiece like Come Away With Me would be next to impossible, but lo and behold, Muthajones has incorporated other styles in her light and mellow jazz inflections.  The wait has been worth it, the music still melodic and wonderful.  Muthajones does it again!

They're little known in the USA, having released only one album here as well as a track on the Mission: Impossible soundtrack (versus 5 albums, 3 EP's, and a plethora of great singles/b-sides in Australia). Standout albums are Double Allergic (their 2nd) and Internationalist (3rd). They continue to rock it with a 5th album release in mid-2003. B000002J1U|4.0|In the grand scheme of things, Led Zeppelin's third record (1970) was the most dramatic shift the band had ever taken from its previous releases, but was necessary to produce their best record a year later.  It is often referred to as the &quot;acoustic&quot; record, but the fact is that it boasts one of the early &quot;heavy metal&quot; tunes (the single, &quot;Immigrant Song&quot;) two outright rockers (&quot;Celebration&quot;, &quot;Out on the Tiles&quot;), and arguably their best original blues song (&quot;Since I've Been Loving You&quot;).  The other six songs are acoustic, but explore a number of diverse avenues, from pure blues (&quot;Hats Off to (Roy) Harper&quot;) to traditional folk (&quot;Gallow's Pole&quot;) to hand-clapping boogie (&quot;Bron-Yr-Aur Stomp&quot;) to spacey pop (&quot;Tangerine&quot;) to affecting ballads (&quot;That's The Way&quot;).  I highly recommend this LP and 'Physical Graphitti' as a starting point for anyone who wants to get beyond obvious hit records down into the real LZ.

B000002JSP|4.0|As history states, Jimmy Page helmed the band for 'Presence' (1976) and Robert Plant helmed the band for this record (1979), the last true studio album from a legendary band.  Because of the changes made in the sound, and most notably the addition of synths and a different vocal style by Robert Plant, it is hard to judge this record in a vacuum without the benefit of seeing where the band would go next.  That is, as Led Zeppelin III is often judged as a misstep, it was a necessary step to get to the arguably best record, &quot;IV&quot;.  That said, it is undeniably better than its predecessor and has a number of tunes worthy of inclusion as official LZ classics, such as &quot;In the Evening&quot;, &quot;All My Love&quot;, &quot;Fool in the Rain&quot;, and the often overlooked, but elegant blues of &quot;I'm Gonna Crawl&quot;.

B000002JSN|4.0|Like the fourth record (1971), the double LP 'Physical Graphiti' (1975) was very much a culmination of everything that the band had done before and would do in the future.  &quot;Ten Years Gone&quot; and &quot;Houses of the Holy&quot; sounded a lot like something off of . . . well, 'Houses of the Holy' (1972), and &quot;Black Country Woman&quot;, &quot;Boogie with Stu&quot;, and &quot;Down by the Seaside&quot; echoed 'Led Zeppelin III.' On the other side of the coin, the toned-down vocal performance on &quot;Trampled Underfoot&quot; and the ethereal keyboards on &quot;In the Light&quot; would precipitate tunes like &quot;In the Evening&quot; on the last true studio record, 'In Through the Out Door' (1979).  But the real essential here is the epic, &quot;Kashmir&quot;, which plays like a cross between &quot;Stairway to Heaven&quot; and &quot;Immigrant Song&quot;.  However, there is certainly some filler here, like &quot;The Rover&quot; and &quot;Night Flight&quot;.  For this reason, I would recommend this record only for those who already have the LZ essentials and would like to dig deeper.
B0000CDLA7|4.0|After pushing their progressive/experimental roots are far as they could go on their previous two records SCENES FROM A MEMORY and SIX DEGREES OF INNER TURBULENCE, Dream Theater finally decided to scale down a little bit and deliver the classic-style heavy metal album they've always wanted to do.  The result is TRAIN OF THOUGHT, a dark, heavy, and punishing 7-song set that never relents from the first song to the last (with the exception of the moving 3-minute interlude &quot;Vacant,&quot; which provides a much needed rest from all the heaviness).  Similar in style and tone to their third album AWAKE, but much more straightforward and less diverse, ToT has its share of flaws, but all around Dream Theater have nearly successfully managed to create the metal juggernaut they wanted to make.<br />Out of the seven songs on here, these are my absolute favorites on the record:<br />&quot;As I Am&quot; (track 1)--What a killer opener!  Despite its 7+ minute running time, this is probably the simplest and most straightforward of all of DT's long songs, but that doesn't make it bad.  Nice defiant lyrics, great catchy chorus, earth-shaking grooves from John Myung and Mike Portnoy, and a scorching guitar solo from Petrucci.  What more could you ask for?<br />&quot;Honor Thy Father&quot; (track 4)--This 10-minute monster is the heaviest and most brutal song on the album.  Mike's lyrics, which are about his intense disdain and hatred towards his stepfather, fit the mood of the music and singer James LaBrie unleashes every vocal arsenal he's capable of delivering, from hushed vocals, to sinister snarls, to soaring Maiden-esque vocals, to even semi-rapped (!) dialogue.  Awesome.  A ripping keyboard solo from Jordan and great riffage from Petrucci round this track out.<br />&quot;Stream of Consciousness&quot; (track 6)--This 11-minute instrumental is my favorite song on the album, and may be one of the most well-crafted and composed pieces I've ever heard, from DT or otherwise.  Thesame melody is repeated throughout, as the band twist and turn it in various directions.  It's amazing how smoothly the song flows.  Lovely guitar and keyboard solos, pitch-perfect drumming from Portnoy, and a downright groovy bass solo section from Myung that would make Tony Levin proud.  Just an amazing piece.<br />&quot;In the Name of God&quot; (track 7)--At 14 minutes, this is the longest on here, and one of the more powerful songs DT has written in quite some time.  This song is about religious hypocrisy and how so-called &quot;leaders&quot; use God and religion to do their evil deeds on society.  By far, this is Petrucci's best lyrical effort since the &quot;Mind Beside Itself&quot; trilogy and &quot;Lines in the Sand,&quot; and the band's musicianship shines best on here (love those Latin rhythms around the 9 minute mark).  James also delivers one of his best vocal performances to date, which says a lot.<br />For the most part, ToT is a solid metal album and it's great to see DT rocking out more than ever before.  However, I can't give it the full 5 stars for a couple of reasons.  For one thing, &quot;Endless Sacrifice&quot; starts off as a great song with more great vocals from James and heartfelt lyrics from Petrucci, but then it falls apart around the 5 minute mark with a pretentious and overlong instrumental section that doesn't fit the dark vibe of the song AT ALL.  It seems to be just put there for the sake of being there.  When Jordan does that brief cartoon riff in the middle, I was shaking my head in disbelief.  Also, John Petrucci's guitar work, while great in some spots, lacks the diversity and emotion of his earlier work and he just seems to be doing '80s-style shredding just because he can.  The guitar solos for &quot;As I Am&quot; and &quot;SOC&quot; are the only ones I can say that moved me, but not on the other songs unfortunately.<br />Despite those gripes, TOT has a number of things going for it.  This has to be the best-sounding and best-produced album they've ever recorded, and it's great to hear John Myung's bass loud and upfront in the mix for the first time in a long time.  His bass playing is also very inspired and bouncy.  For me, he's the main reason why this album sounds so good.  Just one man's opinion anyway.  As I said earlier, James and Mike have never sounded better as they do here.  Jordan Rudess isn't as prominent like he was on SIX DEGREES, but he does what he can, and his lush piano outro on &quot;In the Name of God&quot; is sublime.<br />I think I've said enough.  While it can't compare the band's holy trinity of IMAGES &amp; WORDS, AWAKE, and SCENES FROM A MEMORY, TRAIN OF THOUGHT shows that Dream Theater are still evolving and doing a damn fine job of it.  As one reviewer said, they put the metal back into progressive metal.
B000002JSR|3.0|Released in 1982, two years after the band disbanded, 'Coda' (1982) has only one truly indispensible track, a 1970 rehearsal version of &quot;I Can't Quit You Babe&quot; (originally from the first record).  Also included is a well-executed cover tune (&quot;We're Gonna Groove&quot;), an unremarkable drum solo (&quot;Bonzo's Montreaux&quot;), an outtake from Led Zeppelin III (&quot;Poor Tom&quot;), an outtake from 'Houses of the Holy' (&quot;Darlene&quot;), and three outtakes from their last record, the most interesting of which is the punkish &quot;Wearing and Tearing&quot;.  Bottom line: this should be the last addition to your collection.
B000002HPT|3.0|Although I've always been a little skeptical about Dream Theater's ability to TKO any other band on the face of the planet within 12 bars of music (a philosophy strictly adhered to by many of their loyal fans), never did I expect the champs of progressive metal to arrive in the latter half of 1997 with this much fat around their waste. To be fair, I'll say up front that there's some truly stellar material on this album. The problem is that the bulk of Dream Theater's bloated new epic is just plain tired- not only are old innovations now cliches, but there is just such little effort put into three quarters of the songwriting on &quot;Falling Into Infinity&quot; that even die-hard fans should be disappointed. <br />To avoid having this review sound like one big downward spiral, I'll start with FII's strong points. The good news is that a few more classics are added to the Dream Theater canon in &quot;New Millenium&quot; and &quot;Hell's Kitchen&quot;. Many may protest the inclusion of the latter, but I feel it's one of the few times the band have achieved a somber emotional vibe without lapsing into syrupy melodrama. Of all the influences John Petrucci attempts to absorb into his repertoire, the Satch-like riffs on &quot;Hell's Kitchen&quot; (among others) are one of the few that don't sound contrived. Other obvious influences that sound little more than derivative are Queen, Styx, Pink Floyd and even Dream Theater themselves (&quot;Burning My Soul&quot; is a total rewrite of &quot;Pull Me Under&quot;). Overall the shorter songs are far more provocative and consistent than the longer titles, a trend which seems at odds with the epic virtuosity the band are famed for. At first glance, seeing &quot;Lines In The Sand&quot; (12 minutes) and Trial Of Tears (13 minutes- a three part suite) on the back cover will be enough to interest fans of &quot;Metropolis&quot; and &quot;A Change Of Seasons&quot;. What a disappointment, then, to find that these two songs are possibly theleast progressive on the entire album. It seems the band was going for a middle ground between the instrumental sensationalism of their earlier epics and the dead serious emotion of their ballads (which, if you ask me, more often than not have come off as too petulant with a serious lack of irony). There was nothing wrong with this approach, until they decided to use it on their showcase pieces. The simple fact is that Dream Theater lacks the emotional maturity to manipulate the listener's mood over even as large a spectrum as an entire album, let alone a 13 minute song. This emotional immaturity can easily be gleaned by a quick glance through FII's lyric sheet. Most if not all of the songs seem as though they were written from a template; there are a wealth of unimaginative mixed metaphors (&quot;faith don't pay the rent that's overdue&quot;), overfamiliar symbolism (&quot;swept away with the tide/ through the holes in my hands&quot;), primitive rhyme schemes (&quot;it's alright/ it's OK/ it happens every single day&quot;), and just plain nonsense (&quot;where midnight hysteria's no big surprise&quot;). Every line in every song is but a mere shadow of an idea- an aping of genius passed down through hundreds of generations of declining talent. <br />Many have noted the slightly muffled drums which appear courtesy of new producer Kevin Shirley, but the rest of the instrumentation sounds fine, and the band have only themselves to blame for failing to come up with more than an EP's worth of good material. It's obvious musicianship is Dream Theater's strong suit. It's just a shame the band don't realize it. Instead, they saddle themselves with pretensions they can't hope to fulfill, in the process reducing the songwriting to a virtual catalog of '70s hard rock cliches. I read an interview in which James LaBrie is quoted as saying they plan on being a band that sells a guaranteed two million records with each release (Rush is the apparent benchmark for this figure). That could explain the mass production feel of &quot;Falling Into Infinity&quot;, but it doesn't excuse it.

B00006IU73|5.0|This is the first Porcupine Tree I bought. I actually saw them live too. B000002H6C|5.0|maybe a lot of you weren't around when this thing came out but it brings back memories of junior high with every metalhead wearing &quot;and justice for all&quot; t-shirts like it was their religion. it was a record a ton of metalheads identified with yet at the same time had personal effects on probably millions of metal geeks while they were trying to copy pushead drawings in their room thinking how much their parents/school sucked.<br />the production is perfect for a thrash metal record. its just very dark and isolated and captures a real &quot;black&quot; feeling when listening to it. sure, everyone complains about the lack of bass guitar in the mix but seriously - the guitar production/tracking is unrivaled to ANY record to date except maybe Pantera's &quot;vulgar display of power&quot; in the thrash genre... every track whops your speakers. every melodic breakdown is like some epic war song with layers upon layers.<br />the lyrics were metallica's best ever and held some soul to them. in total, youll never see a record like this again in many aspects. in musicianship, in production and holding such timelessness for such an aggressive record.<br />dont kid yourself, all of metallica's stuff predating this is all awesome in its own individual way as they matured the sound. this just happens to be the pinnacle of the art - capturing a time when metallica was technically beautiful and well thought out.

B000001GPW|5.0|This is one of those legendary re-releases from the golden halls of Deutsche Grammophon-dom that is sure to make you shiver with amazement.  The sound-job here is incredible.  I simply couldn't believe that this stuff was done in 1960.  There's not even the tiniest TRACE of hiss here.  I've heard recordings from 2003 that impressed me less than this.<br />Bartk's three phenomenal piano concertos metamorphose into magnficent and debilitatingly mind-blowing putty in the hands of Ferenc Fricsay and Gza Anda.  Bartk's compatriots were probably more influential than anybody else in preserving and in some cases establishing his reputation after his death, above all in the German-speaking countries, which had been intellectually zapped after World War II.  These DG recordings from 1960 and 1961 are explosive testimony to Fricsay and Anda's brilliance.  Bartk's concertos pound and pulsate with orchestal thump and shimmer with pianistic glitter like you just wouldn't believe.<br />Mind-expanding music, coupled with a totally revelatory recording.  Miss it and die!

0064400018|5.0|Life is hard living on the frontier of Wisconsin in the 1870's.  Laura is only a little girl, but she still needs to help with chorus around her family's log cabin.  There are wild animals in the woods, and they must provide for themselves since the nearest town in hours away.  But it's not all hard work.  If Pa's not tired, he might entertain his daughters with a story or by playing his fiddle.  With family relatively nearby to visit, life is certainly never dull.<br />I had not read these books since I was a child until picking this up to reread.  I had forgotten how entertaining they really are.  There is no real plot, just a collection of stories covering a year in the life of the Ingalls family.  This makes sense since they really are an autobiographical work.  Still, the simple charm of the stories sucked me right in and I had a hard time putting the book down.  There is plenty of detail here to give anyone a good picture of daily life during this time.  And I must mention the illustrations by Garth Williams that greatly add to the book.<br />There's a reason these books are so well loved 70 years after they were written.  They are an entertaining look at everyday life in a different time and place.  This is a book to treasure.

Pitt declares that you cannot plumb the true depth of your manhood without fighting? Yes, the film does seem to be something of a rant against our consumerist American culture, but we must remind ourselves that previous generations of young men worked hard and died hard so that we in this age could know comfort, safety, immense material well being, and few real hardships. I do have to say that though, it doesn't sound like they are really trying to copy anyone or anything, just doing music that they thought sounded cool while tripping and they wanted the world to hear it.  I think Mick Jagger was quoted with saying &quot;We took too much acid while recording that.&quot; I don't know how accurate that quote is but he did say something similar about taking too much acid.  When bands take alot of acid, you get a psychadelic album, look at Pink Floyd's Piper at the Gates of Dawn, Jimi Hendrix's Electric Lady Land, Bob Dylan's Blonde on Blonde, and Syd Barrett's solo albums.  I think Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts club band was somewhat psychadelic but it was a pop-psychadelic, something made to bring the psychadelia to the mainstream, and make that kind of music more accessible.  This stones album is far from easily accessible though.  The more you listen to it, the more you appreciate it.  I for one wish that the Stones did more psychadelic stuff, but we are still left with a great catalog from a great band.  You can't hate on one album because it was completely different than anything else they did.  One of the most underappreciated albums of all time, and one of my favorites.
B00005V1Y0|5.0|I must admit, it took me approximately 20 minutes to actually get into this movie. I so wanted to shut if off, but I gave it the benefit of the doubt and decided to give it more time. I am extremely happy that I did.<br />While this is not a 'masterpiece' as 'Moulin Rouge', it is definately VERY good. The acting was stupendous. The actors made me feel that the story was very real. In a very 'slight' way, I was reminicant of 'Dirty Dancing'.<br />Scott is this Awesome ballroom dancer who does not adhere to 'Strictly Ballroom' rules. He loses a major competition due to his unorthodox dance moves. His overly dramatic dance partner dumps him right before another major competition, and poor Scott is left partnerless. In appears an extremely 'ugly duckling' who wants to dance with him. What happens next is ..... well, I guess you should watch it to know the rest.<br />Overall this was a delightfully lighthearted movie with some poignant scenes that will leave you teary eyed. I recommend it wholeheartedly.

Some of the lyrics are a little silly or have little or no meaning, but the musick more than makes up for it.  Just pure energy and rawness.  Dave Grohl played most of the instruments on here because there really wasn't a band yet.  Thats why this cd is so good because Dave is a great Musician.  If you like your musick, raw, fast, with lots of energy definitley check this out.
B00003CXCT|1.0|I loved Star Wars and The Empire Strikes Back and liked Return of the Jedi when they were in theaters from 1977-84. But George Lucas committed an unforgivable sin when he re-edited the movies for the \\"Special Editions\\": the complete altering/butchering of the previously excellent but now terrible Greedo scene. There are also other annoying changes I can't quite remember, along with some positive changes to the backgrounds and special effects. But it's the awful Greedo scene change that stays with me - it completely ruined the movie and soured me on Star Wars for good. Apparently the original versions - the ones that made Mr. Lucas his fame and fortune, the ones that were loved by all  - are not going to be released on DVD. Steven Spielberg knew better with E.T. and released both versions; but then Spielberg is a classy and honorable man, unlike his pal Lucas. Lucas is truly insulting his audience (or what is left of it after 2 mind-numbingly awful sequels) and he does not deserve a penny of your hard earned money unless he releases the original movies either alone or in a set with the Special Editions. Please do not let your love of Star Wars blind you from protesting his revisionist butchery. BOYCOTT THE STAR WARS DVDS!

B00009W0U4|4.0|perhaps one of the most shocking films i've seen in the past year or so, i'm having a difficult time placing a star rating on this review but let me give you some facts if nothing else. for starters, monica belluci is one of the most beautiful in the actress in the business & i hated watching her gruesome rape scene(even though this isn't the most graphic scene in the film) this montage alone was perhaps the most scary rape scene since baise moi or i spit on your grave. having said this, i can respect the artistry of the film & the terrific performances but i couldn't bring myself to watch it more than once. gaspar noe has a style here similiar to nolan's memento(although a little less confusing i believe) which is cool but certain scenes here tend to drag including the senseless acts of hatred & violence. irreversible opens up with a naked old man sitting on a bed telling us how time manages to literally destroy everything & we should already be forewarned that nothing good could possibly happen throughout the course of 90 odd minutes. he then tells a younger gentleman how his young daughter was taken away from him after he sexually molested her. yuck! in the next scene, we see two young men searching all over an s&m gay club to find some man & we have no understanding as to the urgency of finding this mysterious character. needless to say, you learn more information about each character or event with each montage. in essence, each montage shows us more detail as to what has transpired & what will lead up to the violent chain of events which are shown in the second scene. i should make a point that watching a man's arm broken by another man & then seeing a man's face literally crushed is a bit excessive for an artsy film so this may disturb many viewers. as i stated earlier, the rape scene isn't the only harrowing or intense scene in irreversible. there isn't really a whole lot i can gather from this film except that the terrible things we do to one another often are permanent & humans by nature are barbaric in ways we can't possibly imagine. definately not a feel good film by any means & most viewers will perhaps be subject to much nausea after watching but i still tend to believe irreversible will have a grand cult following for some strange reason. i give it 4 stars out of a possible 5 for great acting, nausea inducing camera-work, & a decent film-making style. the dialogue is an honorable mention but most people will probably only view this film for one obvious reason. they will want to see if this film is as shocking & truly repulsive as so many have stated before me. if you loved memento or baise moi, probability suggests you will probably want to see this one too. it's hard to believe though that you can actually purchase this in a store like best buy. wait a second, best buy also sold a faces of death box set so i'm not too surprised after all.re permanent & humans by nature are barbaric in ways
